formalText: Discussed with him how many of his feelings could be stemming from the feeling that someone is encroaching on his space.
He feels a little out of control.
His anger might be about feeling shut out or feeling like an outsider or feeling encroached upon or just not being able to be left alone peacefully.
There's a lot of sadness because he is aware of having been having this feeling as a kid.
Will see him at 3:10pm tomorrow
Patient states, "I'm super fucking annoyed with every little thing"
He talked about how he didn't like the opposite of feeling really lethargic and kind of melancholy.
The moments of annoyance are so intense he describes it like giving himself a headache.
He feels childish and amateur for feeling this way
He explains how on days like this when it is bad, he is paralyzed for the day.
He can't do anything.
He can't think straight.
He can't really enjoy anything.
Most of his stories include feeling claustrophobic including an experience at Dunkin Donuts parking, one with his girlfriend, one driving, one in Starbucks waiting in line
He states he doesn't like getting so worked up about these things.
He feels like the underlying thing under his annoyance is probably an old revelation or situation.
He was thinking about being a kid when he lost his temper.
Sometimes he can guess how he will feel and that there will be
some little tick.
He had a recurring dream that felt like a metaphor for his situation about how it felt as if his car was driving him.
When he was a kid, he doesn't think he felt claustrophobia.
In the past he was very sensitive to noise and still is slightly.
He loves it with people around, but he also wants to be left alone
Although noise bothers him, he feels he has gotten really good at being okay and living in a society.
He thinks about his past when he was an only child and I was most loved when there was there was no other baby in the family.
